title: Virgin and Child (Life, Death, and Salvation: Stories of the Renaissance)
transcript:
Narrator: Curator, Rebecca Long.

Rebecca Long: So we’re looking at a <music begins> 13th Century carved ivory Madonna and Child.

Narrator: Curator, Martha Wolff.

Martha Wolff: She’s very solid. She’s really grounded and seated on her throne that’s at the same time really tender. The expression of the Christ Child in particular is delightful, humorous, lively. He’s holding a little bird.
<laughter>

Martha Wolff: I didn’t look it up.
<laughter>

Martha Wolff: It’s probably a goldfinch or something.

Rebecca Long: It’s probably a goldfinch, yeah.

Martha Wolff: Yeah.

Rebecca Long: This, it’s a symbol, a traditional symbol of the Passion of Christ.

Martha Wolff: That has, is partly broken, and she’s just gazing benignly really at him, but tenderly as well.

Rebecca Long: To me, what’s fascinating about this object is that story of the international trade in ivory that was allowing these to become so popular as luxury goods.

Martha Wolff: This ivory, which comes from Northern France in the first half of the 13th Century, is the beginning of a great influx of ivory into Northern Europe and the establishment of a real center for the carving of ivory and real advances in the way the tusk was used and the forms were developed within the confines of that curving shape.
